content.title: Lesson 1: Introduction to the Energy for Development pathway

content.text: Energy powers our world — from lighting our homes to running factories and hospitals.

Uninterrupted access to energy is essential for critical social services, including healthcare, water supply, education, heating, and cooling. Energy fundamentally shapes our living standards, safety, and capabilities, driving economic growth and enabling both social and economic development. Beyond comfort, energy ensures security, helps meet basic needs and rights such as clean water and sanitation, and enhances public safety

concepts.title: Fossil fuels dominate
concepts.body: Oil, coal, and natural gas are the largest primary energy sources.

concepts.title: Renewables are making an impact
concepts.body: Solar, wind, and bioenergy contribute significantly, but less than fossil fuels.

concepts.title: Energy losses
concepts.body: Gray areas show energy lost during transformation and transmission.

content.text: Significant disparities exist globally in energy use, prosperity, health, political influence, and resource demands

The quality of life in developed nations today is largely due to abundant and affordable fossil fuel availability over the past century. Comparing per capita energy consumption highlights the stark differences between regions and countries (see Figure 4). For example, the average American uses 12 times more energy than the average Indian, consuming in one month what an Indian consumes in a year. The contrast is even starker between North America and Africa, where the average North American consumes more than 50 times the energy of the average African. Similarly, the average Briton uses twice as much energy as the average Brazilian.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: Ut quaerat numquam eius quaerat quaerat magnam.

takeaways.title: Transitioning to sustainable energy brings transformative advantages
takeaways.description: such as enhancing energy security by reducing dependence on fossil fuel imports, making energy more affordable through declining renewable costs, improving public health by reducing air pollution, and driving job creation.

takeaways.title: The world has made notable strides toward sustainable energy
takeaways.description: with renewable energy capacity growing rapidly and the number of people without electricity decreasing gradually. However, progress is uneven, with Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Landlocked Developing Countries (LLDCs), and Small Island Developing States (SIDS) lagging far behind, emphasizing the need for targeted efforts to bridge this gap.

takeaways.title: Current efforts and pledges to reduce CO2 emissions
takeaways.description: are insufficient to achieve the 1.5°C target of the Paris Agreement. A significant gap remains, requiring accelerated policy implementation, technological innovation, and international collaboration to close the emissions gap and meet global climate goals.
